image:image.image:title: Sinosauropteryx sp IVPP V12415 tail taphonomy
image:image.image:caption: Diagram of the tail tip of IVPP V12514, referred to Sinosauropteryx sp. by Lingham-Soliar et al., 2007. Black refers to the presence of cracks between subslab sections and vertebrae/shevrons. A, original preservation, with numbers reflecting vertebral sequences by proximality. c, "collagen;" s, "scales;" ?, unknown, unremarked. B, my interpretation of these structures, with reds to oranges reflecting gradient of integumental preservation (red, filaments; orange, varying degrees of filament-less regions of the bedding plane or prepared regions). f, filaments; i,. inclusions or impressions of foreign objects, possibly fruits, seeds, or flower ovaries; tf, trace fossils? also, possibly preparation marks; tm, tooling marks.

image:image.image:title: Sinosauropteryx integument examination smll
image:image.image:caption: Fossil (in A) and closeups (B-D) of IVPP V12415, referred to Sinosauropterys sp. by Lingham-Soliar et al., 2007. Images from and modified from Lingjam-Soliar, 2013. Yellow arrows in A-B indicate direction of lighting; direction in B is the same as in C and D. Rectangle 1 is the closeup of the relevant region of the tail, at the break. B, close up of the break in caudal series, with lavender indicating structures of the slab, either deep impressions or reliefs: c, impressions of the continuing caudal series after the "break"; ftm, fine tooling marks, surrounded halo; i, includions, possibly seeds; s, multilobate structures which may indicate large seeds or flower ovaries. Rectangle 2 is shown in C-D; rectangle 3 is the continuation of the features seen in closeup in rectangle 2 and C-D. C, TLS's attempt to describe the break in the tail, shown in dotted lines, and the features in the slab implied to be scales. Resolution may suggest granulation of the overlying matrix, which has been partially removed in C (inset box at top left in C) shows condition prior to preparation which concerns TLS. Rectangle 4 is shown in close up in D. D, TLS is describing the "collagen" cross-hatching and seeming divisions of scale structures from the lumpy relief features. Remember, in C-D, lighting is from the left and slightly angled up to the right.

image:image.image:title: Directionality of marks
image:image.image:caption: Marks on IVPP V12514, specimen referred to Sinosauropteryx sp. (Lingham-Soliar et al., 2007); modifed from Lingham-Soliar, 2013. A-B and C represent two separate sections of the fossil, but both come from the distal section of tail; C, from the proximal end at the break, and A-B from more distal along the series, albeit at lower resolution. Note that lighting is to the top left.

Only the front half of the lower jaw is known.

image:image.image:title: Banguela bust pencil

image:image.image:title: Banguela skull reconstruction color -sm
image:image.image:caption: Possible skull reconstruction for Banguela oberlii, with the holotype jaw in full color. Banguela oberlii is here hypothesized to be a derived dsungaripterid, though in our phylogenetic analysis (Headden & Campos, 2014) the new taxon was placed basal to other dsungaripterids. Further analysis supports a deeper nesting, but this work was not prepared at the time of publication.

image:image.image:caption: Compound figure from the paper, with an inset box that isn't. All that we know of Banguela oberlii, to date, is from this fragment of the jaw. The skull, however, was rather large.

image:image.image:title: Headden&Campos Banguela compared to Dsungaripterus and Thalassodromeus
Pterosaur Mandibular Symphyses
image:image.image:caption: A figure excluded from the paper due to space and scope. schematic representation of the different mandibular symphyseal morphologies in pterosaurs. A represent the basal pterosaur condition, and resembles the anurognathid condition; B represents the "classic" rhamphorhynchoid morphology, as in Eudimorphodon and Rhamphorhynchus; C represents an hypothetical intermediate between B and D, and is also known in dsungaripterids; and D represents virtually all pterodactyloid pterosaurs in which the upper shelf (dms) is distinctly longer than the ventral one (vms). Both shelves create a "mandibular cavity," here termed a mandibular symphyseal cavity (msc). "a" = alveolar margin, "t" = tomial margin.

image:image.image:title: Figure 4(rev)
image:image.image:caption: Results of our phylogenetic analysis. The figure in the paper is flawed by omission of Vectidraco daisymorrisae, but here it is included properly. Some analyses differ in whether Thalassodromeus + Tupuxuara are close to Tapejaridae, and instead are closer to azhdarchids. We will have to add the characters to a broader analysis and see what effect that work has on this placement, as well as Banguela oberlii's.

image:image.image:title: Tyrannosaurus skull details, cast, BHI 3033 Stan, Witmer sm
image:image.image:caption: Cast of skull of BHIGR 3033, the Tyrannosaurus rex named Stan. A, skull and mandible in lateral view, showing overbite and position and relative shape of ectopterygoid. Hatching on the ectopterygoid shape shows ECP and JUG symphysis; black arrowhead indicates furthest point the jaw can adduct before the bone stops it. B, Both mandibular rami views from the left, showing extreme differences in length. In A and B, white arrows point to margins of the teeth where enamel ends, which can occur at half exposed tooth length; gold arrows indicate resorption pits, where replacement teeth begin to form, but these show no such teeth indicating the teeth are abnormally displaced. C, Skull in ventral view, showing foramina of premaxilla (gold arrowhead), distinct pits (white arrowheads)

image:image.image:title: Tyrannosaurus Palate Views Muscle Relationships sm
image:image.image:caption: Skulls of Tyrannosaurus rex in ventral view, with attached mandibles. A, skull based roughly on AMNH FR 5027; B, skull based on AMNH FR 5027, but with left and right jaws shortened as in BHOGR 3033, Stan; C, skull showing relationship of palatal (in green) and coronoid (in red) muscles which pass across ectopterygoid.

image:image.image:title: Opening and Closure of Tyrannosaurus rex Jaw sm
image:image.image:caption: Tyrannosaurus rex, skulls based on AMNH FR 5027. A, skull and jaw in lateral view, with A1 being the "normal" condition and A2 being the shorter jaws in BHIGR 3033, Stan; B, same but in sagittal section, so skull and mandible are the right halves. Mandibles in A and B are closed as far as the ectopterygoid will allow. C, skull with jaw open showing relationship of muscles, including those that pass below and above ectopterygoid that might inhibit full closure; C1 is lateral, C2 is medial sagittal section. Black in B and C represent bones of the midline that are sectioned through.

image:image.image:title: Spinosaur jaws modified 2 tooth positions
image:image.image:caption: Illustration of the alveolar shapes and relative positions of the spinosaur rostrum fragments, based on BSP 1912 VIII 19 (after von Stromer, 1915) -- in blue -- and MSNM V4047 (after dal Sasso et al., 2006) -- in red. The mandibles are considered "natural" for this figure. Top: Shapes and arrangement of the alveoli, with the mandible "fit" into the upper jaws as per Premise #3. Bottom: Relative rostral positions of the mandible in "narrow" gauge in rostralmost position, with the first dentary tooth posterior to the third premaxillary (largest) tooth, and in the position argued by dal Sasso et al. (2006).

image:image.image:title: Spinosaur jaws modified 2 mandible position
image:image.image:caption: Spinosaurine cranial fragments in lateral view, based on BSP 1912 VIII 19 (after von Stromer, 1915) and MSNM V4047 (after dal Sasso et al., 2006). C represents a conjoined alveolar view of both specimens. A, "natural" sizes of the fragments in rostral (left) and caudal (right) positions of the mandible, as determined by the the text, and "narrow" and "aligned" gagues, as determined by direction of dental carinae orientation. B, same, but with the mandible increased by 20% in all dimensions. C, "aligned" and "narrow" gauges of the mandible.

image:image.image:title: Spinosaur jaws modified 2 lateral
image:image.image:caption: Spinosaurine cranial fragments in lateral view, based on BSP 1912 VIII 19 (after von Stromer, 1915) and MSNM V4047 (after dal Sasso et al., 2006). Top two: "natural" size; bottom two: mandible increased in dimensions by 20%. The first and third images position the mandible rostrally so that the first dentary tooth is immediately caudal to the first premaxillary tooth (absolute maximal length). The second and fourth images position the mandible caudally so that the "terminal rosette" coincides with the "subnarial gap."

image:image.image:title: Proterosuchus fergusi skull sm

image:image.image:title: Chinchilla lanigera skull and jaw motion sm

Positions do not reflect the extreme of positions. Arrows indicate direction of motion in propalinal bite stroke.

image:image.image:title: Tyrannosauru heads skinned sm
image:image.image:caption: "Lip" extent in tyrannosaurs. Top, fully encompassing oral tissues, with an upper and lower band meeting lateral to the teeth. Middle, "malf-lip," with bands of oral tissue around part of the upper jaw, but exposing the teeth. Bottom, the "croc" model, without bands of oral tissue. The top one is favored on this site based on present (circumstantial) data.

image:image.image:title: Tsingtao Google Images First Page
image:image.image:caption: First page of results from Google's image search function for "Tsingtaosaurus" reveals that virtually all reconstructions of the dinosaur were with a single, natural spike on its head.

image:image.image:title: Ingenia_yanshini_skeleton2
image:image.image:caption: Skeleton of Ajancingenia yanshini, including the holotype braincase, manus and pes (MPC-D 100/30), paratype mandible and limbs (MPC-D 100 31). Due to the nature of the issues surrounding consistency of the holotype, only the figured limb material and skull is shown, but substantive vertebral and rib material is known.

image:image.image:title: Conchoraptorine Big Beak skull multiview
image:image.image:caption: Skull of an unnamed Conchoraptor-like oviraptorid. The skull and mandible in various views. From left to right, top to bottom: Skull in anterior, left lateral, posterior, and dorsal view; mandible in dorsal view; skull in ventral view, mandible in ventral view; braincase with lateral bones (postorbital, squamosal, quadrate, and the arms of the paroccipital processes) removed; mandible in left lateral and right medial views. Each square of the grid represents 1 centimeter.

image:image.image:title: Bird tail variation sm
image:image.image:caption: Evolutionary shortening of the tail isn't so simple. A, basal tetanuran had filamentous integument; B, short-tailed maniraptoran oviraptorosaurs appear to have a broad distal fan, but short proximal tail feathers; C, dromaeosaurids had long stiffened tails with distal fans, but almost no proximal feathers; D, Archaeopteryx had relatively long feathers all along the tail; E, a reconstruction of the tail of Shenzhouraptor (Jeholornis) with the basal feathers reconstructed as coverts; F, Shenzhouraptor (Jeholornis) presented as argued by O'Connor et al.; G, a short-tailed bird, Confuciusornis sanctus had two much longer tail feathers; H, the magnificent tail of the male peafowl, Meleagris pavo.

image:image.image:title: Scansoriopterygidae medium
image:image.image:caption: Scansoriopterygidae, including all referred taxa. Scansoriopteryx heilmanni is often considered synonymous with Epidendrosaurus ningchengensis, both are probably juveniles, and they may in turn be synonymous with Epidexipteryx hui (in which case Scansoriopteryx heilmanni has priority above both other taxa).

image:image.image:title: juvie tyrants in scale
image:image.image:caption: Selected portions of juvenile tyrannosaurid skulls. All scale bars represent 5 cm, and so all skulls are to scale. LH PV18 is the holotype of Raptorex kriegsteini (after Sereno et al., 2009); MPC-D 107/7 is after Tsuihiji et al. (2011); IVPP V4878 is the holotype of Shanshanosaurus huoyanshanensis (after Currie and Dong, 1999); MPC-D 100/1844 is the holotype of Alioramus altai (after Brusatte et al., 2009).

image:image.image:title: Raptorex femur section age
image:image.image:caption: Histological section of the femur of LH PV18, holotype of Raptorex kriegsteini Sereno et al. (2009). Blue bars represent bands of bone tissue, where 1-3 represent LAGs according to Fowler et al. (2011). "?" represents the base of bone below LAG 1, and may represent the portions of a remodelling zone, or an additional eroded LAG. "s" indicates the surficial bone, and "mc" the medullary cavity.

image:image.image:title: Shanshanosaurus fig 3
image:image.image:caption: Vertebrae of IVPP V4878, holotype of Shanshanosaurus huoyanshanensis Dong, 1977 (after Currie and Dong, 2000). Note variabkle articulation and closure of sutures.

image:image.image:title: Erickson et al tyrannosaur growth curves
image:image.image:caption: Hypothesized timing of sexual maturity in North American tyrannosaurs. From Erickson et al. (2010), after Erickson et al. (2004) and Schweitzer et al. (2005).

image:image.image:title: oviraptorid ENF position
image:image.image:caption: A chart of snouts for oviraptorosaurs; all illustrations produced by me. A, Incisivosaurus gauthieri; B, Caudipteryx sp.; C, Caudipteryx zoui, grey parts restored; D, Avimimus portentosus; E, "Mitrata" oviraptorid, undescribed; F, Wulatelong gobiensis; G, Oviraptor philoceratops; H, Citipati osmolskae; I, MPC-D 100/42; J, Nemegtomaia barsboldi; K, Rinchenia mongoliensis; L, Banji long; M, ZPAL MgD-I/95, often referred to "Ingenia" mongoliensis, but a conchoraptorine instead; O, Conchoraptor gracilis; P, Khaan mckennai. All skulls are to scale. Horizontal grey lines reflect the ventral jugal margin, which approximates "natural attitude" of the head at rest; orange-ish arrows point to the level of the ventral margin of the narial fenestra, and the grey box illustrates the extent to which this expands above or below the line. Asterisks indicate lack of reliable information.

image:image.image:title: Luetal2010 Darwinopterus analysis phylogeny 2
image:image.image:caption: Phylogeny of Pterosaurs from Lü et al., 2010, showing the "50% majority rule" analysis. This output was the product of an aborted analysis, and a full run of this analysis produces a slightly different topology. Witton uses this and a further analysis that ran the same analysis (Unwin, 2010) as the basis for arrangement of taxa in the second section. Red lines refer to general morphotypes among pterosaurs, whilst blue dots refer to three peculiar taxa whose relationships are very contentious (technically, this is also true of Haopterus, but only recently). Grey lines reflect approximate "natural" relationships, which are not indicated by Witton.

image:image.image:title: oviraptorosaur manus w Wulansuhai sm
image:image.image:caption: The hands of oviraptorosaurs, restricted to Caenagnathidae (A-C) and Oviraptoridae (D-M). Colors signify diagnostic attributes of each group, with blue representing caenagnathid features (1-7), red representing oviraptorid features (8-15), green representing "ingeniine" features (16-21) and light orange representing other features (22-24) not evenly distributed among taxa. See text for clarification. A, Chirostenotes pergracilis, based on CMN 2367 and RTMP 79.20.1; B, Hagryphus giganteus, based on UMNH VP 12765; C, Elmisaurus rarus, based on ZPAL MgD-I/98; D, Wulatelong gobiensis, based on IVPP V18409; E, Oviraptor philoceratops, based on AMNH FABR 6517; F, The Zamyn Khondt "oviraptorine," MPC-D 100/42; G, Citipati osmolskae, based on MPC-D 100/979; H, Conchoraptor gracilis, based on MPC-D 100/20; I, Khaan mckennai, based on MPC-D 100/1127; J, Machairasaurus leptonychus, based on IVPP V15979; K, Nemegtomaia barsboldi, based on MPC-D 107/15 and 107/16; L, "Ingenia" yanshini, based on MPC-D 100/30; M, Heyuannia huangi, based on HYMV1-2. All manus are scaled to the same carpal-metacarpal lengths, with missing material shaded.

image:image.image:title: Band vs Bad 2
image:image.image:caption: Left, the BAD (birds are dinosaurs) position, showing several key players mentioned in the text. Right, the BAND (birds are not dinosaurs) position, showing the same members in different positions and with different group names used for some. Yellow to green boxes represent the transition from "simply" feather-like structures to complex, modern-like structures, such as flight feathers. The violet box on right phylogram represents the odd, membraneous squamous structures of Longisquama insignis, while the red box represents Lingham-Soliar's interpretation of coelurosaur "collagen."

image:image.image:title: Longisquama_insignis_skeleton&silhouette_small
image:image.image:caption: An outdated reconstruction of Longisquama insignis (Sharov, 1970), with the limbs held in an erect, potentially terrestrial posture. (I no longer agree with this interpretation.)

image:image.image:title: McKellar amber specimen TMP 96-9-334
image:image.image:caption: TMP 96.9.334, a specimen of amber from the late Campanian of Grassy Laek, Alberta, with a feather-like inclusion argued to be a stage II type feather. Modified from McKellar et al. (2011), supplemental online material.

image:image.image:title: Martin evolution of birds
image:image.image:caption: Martin's (2008) concept of avian evolution, progressing from a "proavis" represented by Longisquama insignis (A), to a "tetrapteryx" stage as envisioned by C. william Beebe and represented by Microraptor gui (B), and an "urvogel" stage of wing-flappers as represented by Archaeopteryx lithographica (C).

image:image.image:title: TLS Sinosauropteryx as fin-tailed
image:image.image:caption: Lingham-Soliar's 2011 concept of the non-fluffy, aquatic Sinosauropteryx prima.

image:image.image:title: snh-obl-enf proportions
image:image.image:caption: Scatter plot of distribution of coelurosaurs (and some carnosaurs) based on the ratio of the subnarial height/oral basal length beneath the external narial fenestra, and against the angle of the ENF, described in the text. Below, the snout of Incisivosaurus gauthieri describes how the measurements are derived.

image:image.image:title: md2-ii-md2-i ratios
image:image.image:caption: Distribution along a continuous series, describing

image:image.image:title: QuestionableCervicals
image:image.image:caption: Cervical vertebrae of proposed oviraptorosaurs. A, MACN-PV 622, the El Brete "oviraptorosaur," in 1, dorsal, 2, left lateral, 3, cranial and 4, ventral views. B, Thecocoelurus daviesi Seeley, 1886, holotype NHMUK R901, in 1, slightly cranial dorsal, 2, right lateral, 3, cranial, 4, ventral and 5 left lateral views. Scale bar in A equals 1 cm, in B 2 cm. A after Agnolin and Martinalli (2007), B after Naish and Martill (2002).

image:image.image:title: Xversusplus shaped vertebrae
image:image.image:caption: Posterior cervical vertebrae of several maniraptorans showing the difference between "X"- and "+"-shaped zygapophyseal arrangements. A, BEXHM 2008.14.1, the Ashdown maniraptoran; B, Microvenator celer (Ostrom, 1970), holotype AMNH 3041; C, Nomingia gobiensis (Barsbold et al., 2000), holotype MPC-D 100/119. 1 shows the mean long axial array of the zygapophyses towards the midline, and 2 shows the axes in isolation. Vertebrae are not to scale. A after Naish and Sweetman (2011), B after Makovicky & Sues (1998), C after Barsbold et al. (2000).

image:image.image:title: prezyg orientation angles
image:image.image:caption: Posterior cervical or anterior dorsal vertebrae with the angle of the prezygapophysis in lateral aspect, in left lateral view. A, Deinonychus antirrhopus Ostrom (1969a), YPM 5204, anterior dorsal (Ostrom, 1969b notes this is as anterior as the fourth dorsal). Note the anteriorly-placed hypapophysis and pleurocoel. B, Nomingia gobiensis Barsbold et al. (2000), holotype MPC-D 100/119, posterior cervical. C, Microvenator celer Ostrom (1970), holotype AMNH 3041, posterior cervical vertebra. 1 indicates an overlay of the vertebra with the angle of the prezygapophyses against two axes: a line drawn from the floor of the anterior end to the posterior end of the neural canal, and a line drawn perpendicular to it at the dorsal end of the anterior face of the acjoining centrum. Note in C the face is inclined ventrally; 2, the lines of axes and angle isolated.

image:image.image:title: Nomingia cervicodorsals
image:image.image:caption: Nomingia gobiensis (Barsbold et al., 2000), holotype MPC-D 100/119. Anteriormost presacrals in left lateral and dorsal views. Small white arrows indicate hypapophyses, small black arrows indicate pneumatic foramina and (in the neural arches) pneumatic pleurocoels; large white arrow indicates a large epipophysis on the last cervical, and large black arrows indicate un-obliterated neurocentral sutures, which are not apparent on the dorsals. Scale bar equals 10 cm.

image:image.image:title: Avimimus cervicodorsals
image:image.image:caption: Avimimus portentosus (Kurzanov, 1981), cervicodorsals. A, sequence of three consecutive vertebrae in left lateral view with large hypapophyses; B, same vertebrae in anterior view; C, same, in posterior view. Black arrows in A indicate pneumatic foramina. "hy" and white arrows points to hypapophyses, largely for the anterior and posterior views.

image:image.image:title: Nomingia MPC 100-119 cervicodorsals
image:image.image:caption: Nomingia gobiensis, holotype MPC-D 100/119 posterior cervicals and anterior dorsals, articulated series.

image:image.image:title: Troodontid ant dorsal
image:image.image:caption: Troodontid cervical, after makovicky and Norell (2004). Referred to Troodon formosus, and likely part of the Two Medicine Formation troodontid collection at the MOR. In ventral and left lateral views.

image:image.image:title: Wealden maniraptoran BEXHM 2008-14-1 (2 small)
image:image.image:caption: BEXHM 2008.14.1, a posterior cervical from the Ashdown Beds of the Wealden, Wadhurst Clay Formation, of England, near Hastings in eastern East Sussex. The vertebrae are modified from Naish and Sweetman (2011) and arranged so that each adjacent vertebra is 90 degrees to the others. As modified, grey areas indicate missing material and possible outlines of the regions. Abbreviations: f, lateral neurocentral and central fossae, hy, hypapophysis, pp, parapophysis. Scale bar is true for all vertebrae. Because of the angles by which the vertebra was photographed, various views are not perfectly aligned with one another..

image:image.image:title: Conch jaw muscles positions open&closed
image:image.image:caption: Muscle lines of action. Different muscles orient separately when the jaw is protracted (A, D), at "normal position" (B, E) and retracted (C, F). Perhaps interestingly, the position of the symphysis when the jaw is closed (A-C) is directly beneath the ventral "prongs" of the maxilla no matter how protracted/retracted the jaw becomes.

image:image.image:title: Conchoraptorine beak gap and shapes
image:image.image:caption: Skull of "Big Beak" (PIN uncatalogued), a "conchoraptorine" oviraptorid. A, described the rostral-most occlusion between the jaws, with arrow position 1 indicating the rostralmost occlusion, and 2, the caudalmost occlusion. Arrow 3 indicates the approximate shape of the space between occlusal tomial margins of the upper and lower jaws, a gap perhaps necessitating a rhamphothecal covering to "contain." B, describes the shapes of the rhamphothecae required to fill the gap in A. C, ventral view of cranium with rostral (1) and caudal (2) mandibular occlusal positions indicated, showing shape of upper rhamphothecae, which in D, are splayed somewhat to contact mandibular rhamphothecae. Abbreviations: adch, adductor chamber; ch, choanae; dcp, dentary cornified plate; mcp, maxillary cornified plate; pmcp, premaxillary cornified plates; sofe, suborbital fenestra.

image:image.image:title: Conchoraptorine Skull Muscle Maps Labeled
image:image.image:caption: Skull of "Big Beak" (PIN uncatalogued), a "conchoraptorine" oviraptorid. Skull in various views with origins and insertions colored.

image:image.image:title: Conch muscles - all, small
image:image.image:caption: All of the mandible-moving jaw muscles combined, thus describing the extent of jaw muscles present. Muscles would effectively extend over 1/2 the mandible's total length.

image:image.image:title: Conch mAMEM+mAMEP

Muscles depicted follow common terminology. Also shown is the m. depressor mandibulae, which is here depicted as a single muscle but may be divided in some nonarchosaurs.

In the top section, red is the antorbital fenestra, blue the promaxillary fenestra, and green the maxillary fenestra; oviraptorids may present an additional, more ventral fenestra representing ventral extensions of the antorbital fenestra into the maxillary "body."

image:image.image:title: Caenagnathus mandible tma baseline
image:image.image:caption: Mandible of CMN 8776, holotype of Caenagnathus collinsi Sternberg (1940). The grey box represents the relative aspect of the mandible when positioned conventionally, with the ventral margins of the dentary and retroarticular process forming a baseline. This alters the aspect ratio of the mandible extremely.

image:image.image:title: Conchoraptorine Big Beak skull attitude variation
image:image.image:caption: Skull attitude variation in an oviraptorid, using "Big Beak" (the PIN conchoraptorine). Blue lines depict the bsl (basal skull length), lpa (long palatal axis) and ? (endocranial?). A depicts the bsl at horizontal, B depicts the ? at horizontal, and C depicts the lpa at horizontal. Red lines depict the lma (long mandibular axis) and tma (tomial mandibular axis). Numbers below A depict the degrees of incline above or below the horizontal from the bsl for the lpa and the ?.

All mandible images are positioned so that the rostral tip of the dentary is in the same plane in each image on a vertical axis, while the dorsal margin of the articular, regardless of rotation, is on the same horizontal axis. image:image.image:title: mandibular ramus rotation
image:image.image:caption: Ovals representing a coronal section through a mandibular ramus, here the dentary (with a triangular tooth on top for orientation). A, with the adjusted long and short main axes of the section, and grading through 20 degrees of rotation, then another 20 degrees. The tooth position maintains position on the dorsal margin of the jaw, which adjusts labially or lingually depending on ramus rotation. B, ramus section with labial thickening (representing the ridge, indicate by small red arrows). Notice the greater demarcation of "faces" when the mandible is merely rotated. C, paired mandibular sections with apical teeth not oriented while mandibular rami are, maintaining lingual distance during rotation and thus forming a serially proportionately narrower oral cavity and larger buccal cavity without producing a distinct ridge. White sections represent Meckel's canal.

image:image.image:title: ankylosaur chewing without cheeks
image:image.image:caption: A model for extra oral tissues use in an ankylosaurid skull. A, jaws at rest; B, jaws in abduction, with mandibular rami rotated labially (outward); C, jaws in adduction, with mandibular rami rotated lingually (inward). 2 in B and C represent the inclusion of a bolus (deep orange) which here is sized to roughly be the diameter of the rostral dental row, which the caveat that the bolus can be large (as wide as the caudal tooth row, or rostral beak.

image:image.image:title: ornithischian snout cross-sections
image:image.image:caption: Cross-sections through the rostral maxilla and dentary in three "cheeked" ornithischian clades - Hadrosauroidea, Edmontosaurus annectens; Ankylosauridae, Euoplocephalus tutus; and Ceratopsidae, Centrosaurus apertus. Letters refer to the three possible models, with all taxa showing sessile, lacertilian "lips" (A), and a muscle-less, fleshy "cheek" (B), with the additional model of an ankylosaur (Based on Panoplosaurus mirus) with a buccal plate (B and C for Euoplocephalus tutus only). Euoplocephalus tutus follows Coombs, 1978 and inferences from Witmer & Ridgely, 2008, while Edmontosaurus annectens and Centrosaurus apertus follow inferences from Witmer & Ridgely, 2008 and Bell et al., 2009.

image:image.image:title: Uromastyx and Sphenodon

image:image.image:title: Hallopus skeleton

image:image.image:title: Brusatte&Bhullar cranial morphometric space figure
image:image.image:caption: Plots from Brusatte et al., 2011 (left) and Bhullar et al., 2012 (right). Plots are shown having been run with oviraptorids (top) and without (bottom). Deeper red fields mark out "herbivorous" taxa, while lighter red circles mark out giant-bodied theropods. These tend to plot consistently. Modified from their respective papers.

image:image.image:title: Bhullar paedomorphic PCA plot against phylogeny and heterochrony
image:image.image:caption: Bhullar et al. (2012) demonstrate heterochronic ontogenetic trajectory in theropod phylogeny. The arrow in both plots originated with Euparkeria, but terminates at Gallus. On the left is the original figure from the paper, on the right a modified form from the supplemental online data. Modified from Bhullar et al., 2012.

image:image.image:title: Sakamoto bite estimation in theropods
image:image.image:caption: Three frames of the Sakamoto (2010) analysis, showing the profiles delineating the "weak/fast" bit (exemplifying coelophysoids); and the slow, efficient bites of tyrannosaurs and ornithomimosaurs (tyrannosaurs being more efficient, and faster, than ornithomimosaurs); and finally the highly efficient, low-curve profiles of oviraptorids matched against the weaker avian and dromaeosaurid profiles, which are themselves similar to tyrannosaurs. Modified from Sakamota (2009).

image:image.image:title: Sakamoto PCA analysis of cranial efficiency in theropods
Brusatte cranial morphometric space figure
image:image.image:caption: Brusatte et al.'s morphometric tests results, including oviraptorids (top) and excluding them (bottom). Note that the lower figure is roughly an inversion of the upper figure, merely lacking oviraptorids. This indicates virtually no change to the analysis results while oviraptorids are excluded.

image:image.image:title: Europejara phylogeny and biostratigraphy

The geologic column to the right is mapped to the mandibles, with Europejara olcadesorum in orange, Sinopterus in green (the fourth mandible represents Huaxiapterus jii, which was synonymized with Sinopterus as Sinopterux jii), and blue represents Tupandactylus imperator.

image:image.image:title: Erlikosaurus pes
image:image.image:caption: Pes of GIN 100/111, holotype of Erlikosaurus andrewsi (Barsbold & Perle, 1980). Left, pes in flexor view, after Barsbold & Perle (1980); right, pes in lateral view with digits splayed for viewing, after Perle (1981).

image:image.image:title: Dromaeosaurid pes curling and mt1 orientation
image:image.image:caption: Pes of Velociraptor mongoliensis (Osborn, 1924), and Deinonychus antirrhopus (Ostrom, 1969). A and B modified after Norell & Makovicky (1997, 1998) respectively, and B after Fowler et al. (2011). Scales bars in the original, representing 2cm, 1cm, and 5cm, respectively. White arrows in A and B point to MTI and its articulation with MTII (in A, it is closely associated, in B it is separated). Note the gap between the distal end of MTI in C, while the metatarsal is closely appressed otherwise. Yellow arrows indicate the angle (θ) by which MTI and MTII diverge; it is lowest in A, and higher in B and C.

image:image.image:title: Deinonychosaur ped range of motions
image:image.image:caption: Deinonychosaur pes ranges of motion. Modified from Senter (2009), where I oriented the metatarsals to roughly the same degree. Ungual phalanges are missing in UA 5686, some nonungual phalanges are restroed from plaster in YPM 5205, and the pdII-3 ungual in the latter is considered deformed somewhat by Fowler et al. (2011), noting that Ostrom (1976) described a less-recurved pdII-3u which can substantially alter the range of "curling" or the taxon's position on the cursorial-arboreal gradient (Feduccia, 1993; see criticisms by Glen & Bennett, 2007). Specimens are not to scale.

image:image.image:title: Achillobator_giganticus_skeleton
image:image.image:caption: Achillobator giganticus, a particularly robust dromaeosaurid.

image:image.image:title: Deinonychosaur RPR hypothesis
image:image.image:caption: Deinonychosaurs in relation to the RPR ("ripper") hypothesis presented by Fowler et al. (2011). The illustrations are mine. Characteristics of the changing body proportions and relative size of the limbs and unguals of the manus and pes, as well as of the skull and teeth, indicate a shift from primarily foot-based prey-restraint toward coupled forelimb/hindlimb prey restraint, as indicated by mantling hawks, but augmented with actual holding of the prey by larger-bodied dromaeosaurids (here, Velociraptor mongoliensis). Scale bar equals 20 cm.

image:image.image:title: BALDAUR_FIG_2

image:image.image:title: Ornithodira explained
image:image.image:caption: Crown groups in "modern" Reptilia (rather than using the "classic" definition for only cold-blooded animals, exclusive of Aves). Reptilia includes all non-mammalian amniote crowns, and it might be best to simply qualify it as such. A represents the basic crown tree, while B shows the relative positions of Pterosauria, Scleromochlus, and the clade Ornithodira which contains Pterosauria and Dinosauria (here depicted as the lineage including the stem of crown-Aves).

image:image.image:caption: Caenagnathid mandible with points of interest highlighted, in left lateral view. Each portion of the image is a different set of points, or vertices, from which measurements and axes can be drawn from. Mandible modified after Currie et al., 1994.

image:image.image:title: Caenagnathus mandible axial measurements post-alignment
image:image.image:caption: Caenagnathid mandible with points of interest highlighted, in left lateral view. Each portion of the image is a different set of points, or vertices, from which measurements and axes can be drawn from. Mandible modified after Currie et al., 1994.

image:image.image:title: Caenagnathus mandible associated points
image:image.image:caption: Caenagnathid mandible with points of interest highlighted, in left lateral and dorsal views. Mandible modified after Currie et al., 1994.

image:image.image:title: dog vs fox crocs
image:image.image:caption: Dogs vs Foxes. The "Dog Croc" Araripesuchus wegeneri, African representative of the otherwise South American taxon, is on the left, from Todd Marshall and via the Project Exploration and National Geographic, in conjunction with Sereno & Larsson (2009); I've added a watermark to reduce copyright theft. On right, muscular study of Terrestrisuchus gracilis, after Crush, 1964 (from me, but also with watermark). Compare the legginess.

image:image.image:title: croc vs mammal limb designs
image:image.image:caption: Sprawling vs. Upright limb designs in two mammals (left, brown rat and domestic dog) and two pseudosuchians ("gator" and "running croc").

image:image.image:title: pelvis cross-section
image:image.image:caption: Pelvic cross-sections at the middle of the ilium. A, psuedosuchian-line archosaurs; B, dinosauromorph-like archosaurs. ILI, ilium; ISC, ischium; SAC, sacrum. Grey arrows point to the suprafemoral butress of the ilium, black arrow in "B" to the medial pelvic foramen.

image:image.image:title: Pissarrachampsa sera skull
image:image.image:caption: LPRP/URP 0019, holotype skull of Pissarrachampsa sera Montefeltro et al., 2011. Skull in left lateral and ventral views, modified after the authors.

image:image.image:title: Terrestrisuchus gracilis skeleton large
image:image.image:caption: The "true" dog croc, Terrestrisuchus gracilis.

image:image.image:title: The_Many_Archaeopteryx_by_Qilong

image:image.image:title: majungasaurus vertebral series
image:image.image:caption: Majungasaurus crenatissimus, nearly complete cervical, dorsal, sacral, and anterior caudal vertebral series in ONP. After O'Connor (2007) (see ref. 8).

image:image.image:title: natalid rib cages
image:image.image:caption: Rib cages and vertebral columns of natalid bats. A-D in dorsal view, E-H in left lateral view, and I-L in ventral view. A, E, I are Nyctiellus lepidus, B, F, J are Chilonatalus macer and C, G, K are Chilonatalus micropus, and D, H, L are Natalus tumidirostris. After Plate 18 in Tejedor (2011).

image:image.image:title: Stegosaurus holotype YPM
image:image.image:caption: YPM 1850, holotype of Stegosaurus armatus Marsh (1877). After Galton, 2010. Missing are included sauropod material referred to different taxa.

image:image.image:title: Homalocephale calathoceros
image:image.image:caption: MPC-D 100/1201(formerly, GI SPS 100/51), holotype of Homalocephale calathocercos Maryaska and Osmólska (1974).

image:image.image:title: stegoceras ontogeny colour revised2
image:image.image:caption: Skulls of specimens referred to Stegoceras validum, arranged by relative size (specimen numbers within the figure). In dorsal (above) and right lateral (below) views. Specimens are all to scale.

image:image.image:title: Ornatotholus CT Figure
image:image.image:caption: AMNH FR 5450, holotype of Ornatotholus browni (Wall and Galton, 1979), referred to Stegoceras validum (Galton, 1973, following Scott et al., 2011). Frontoparietal in dorsal, left lateral, and posterior views (left side) and in coronal, sagittal and transverse sections (right side) using high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT).

image:image.image:title: Globidens dakotensis skull
image:image.image:caption: Schematic representation of the skull of quintessential globidont mosasaur, Globidens dakotensis.

image:image.image:title: Conchoraptorine eyeball
image:image.image:caption: Skull of a PIN oviraptorid skull (provisionally, "Big Beak"), as above, but with a green "eyeball" inserted into the orbits. Because of the point of section where the rostral view of the skull is shown, the "eyeball" appears to overlap limiting bones -- this is an illusion.

image:image.image:title: oviraptor_DSC_7781-2
image:image.image:caption: Cast of a skull of an oviraptorid, from Witmer Lab's online collection. Note both the "mitrate" striated premaxillo-nasal crest and the scleral ossicles, which form a complete ring.

image:image.image:title: heterodontosaurus tucki skull sm
image:image.image:caption: SAM PK k1332, skull and mandible referred to Heterodontosaurus tucki, and the basis of virtually all that we know of its skull. Skull and mandible in left lateral and right lateral views, and skull alone in dorsal and ventral views. Despite damage during collection and preparation, this skull is in better condition and is more complete than that of the holotype, SAM PK K337. Modified from appendices in Norman et al., 2011.
